En este lugar encontramos a la señora Yolanda, tiene 30 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene un hijo de 4 años de edad. Su esposo es comerciante. Ella estudio y obtuvo el título de licenciada en la Universidad, en la actualidad trabaja como profesora por contrato en una escuela.

Se dedica a la venta de ropa de todo tipo, su forma de  venta es puerta a puerta, también vende en su  casa hasta donde llegan sus clientes,  trabaja  tres días a la semana desde las 13h00 hasta las 17h00, en estos meses está de vacasiones pero cuando estaba dando clases vendía todos los días a sus amigas en la escuela, deja a crédito a sus clientes  y cobra cada quince días. Su mercadería  la va a comprar a  Guayaquil, lleva en esta actividad por dos años.

Este crédito es para comprar pantalones, camisetas, blusas, ropa de niños, interiores, entre otras prendas. Es socia fundadora del Banco comunal y le gusta por las charlas educativas. Sus sueños son tener un local donde vender sus productos.
texts.en:
Every two weeks the members of the community bank Las Piedras meet in the neighbourhood of Las Piedras located in the parish of Picoaza in the town of Portoviejo. The town is known for its traditional culture, for its happy people, and for its San Pedro and San Pablo celebrations. 

30-year old Yolanda is a member of the bank. She is married and has a 4-year old son. Her husband is a businessman. Yolanda has a university degree and currently works on contract in a school. She also sells all types of clothing from door to door as well as to customers who come to her house.  During the vacations she works at this job three days a week from 1pm to 5pm , but when she is teaching she sells to her friends at the school. She extends credit to her customers and collects from them every two weeks. She buys the merchandise from Guayaquil and has had her business for two years.

The loan will be used to buy pants, shirts, blouses, children’s clothing, underwear etc. Yolanda is a founding member of the bank and particularly enjoys the educational talks. Her dream is to have a stall where she can sell her products.

loans.use: to buy pants, shirts, blouses, children’s clothing, underwear etc

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of various articles for resale at her stall

loans.name: Cissy

texts.en:
Cissy N. lives in the Bwaise neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has 5 children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members -- her late sister’s children. Cissy lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, medication, and food for her family.

To earn a living, Cissy operates a pub. She has been in this business for 9 years, and she works 7 days per week. Cissy sells her products in a retail shop. She generates additional income by renting rooms. She explains that her main business challenges include seasonality and thievery.

Cissy is requesting a loan in the amount of 1,000,000 Ugandan shillings ($425) from MCDT SACCO. The loan proceeds would be used to buy more crates of beer, local gin, and soda. In the future, she hopes to own and operate a beer depot.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional inventory

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph E. is from the village of Poblacion, Don Carlos, Bukidnon. He is 43 years old. Joseph is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Joseph owns & operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing utility van or multi-purpose vehicle services to local community members. Joseph has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 16,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Joseph joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joseph has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase tools needed to provide service. Joseph is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase tools & equipment needed to expand services provided. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Joseph from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tools & equipment needed to expand services provided.

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel B. is from the village of Diamantina, Cabatuan, Isabela. She is 34 years old. Maricel is married and has three school-aged children. 

To make a living, Maricel prepares and sells cooked food for daily meals. Maricel has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Maricel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Maricel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional ingredients to cook more dishes to sell. 

Maricel is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional ingredients to cook more dishes to sell. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Maricel from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional ingredients to cook more dishes to sell

loans.name: Harutyun

texts.en:
Harutyun P. is 49 years old and lives in Vanadzor city. He is married and has three children — two daughters and a son. His daughters are already married and live separately, and his son is in school. 

For about 16 years Harutyun has been engaged in trading men and women clothing and sleepwear at the Vanadzor clothes fair. His wife stays at home and keeps the house.

Harutyun needs a 1,000,000 AMD loan to buy spring and summer clothes to resell.  This is Harutyun’s third loan from Kiva and his 15th loan from Nor Horizon, and he has never been late with his repayments.

loans.use: to buy spring and summer clothes to resell

loans.name: Iuza

texts.en:
Iuza comes from the village of Gora, Imereti Region. He is 54 years old and lives in his home-village with his wife Medea, their 27-year-old daughter and 21-year-old son. 

Iuza G. works in local factory as a specialist and also is actively involved in the family’s agricultural activities. In particular, family has two milk cows and produces cheese, which is sold locally. Also the family has a vineyard (600 grape vines) and sells grapes. Iuza produces wine and sells it in the village. Medea and their son are also involved in the family business. Their daughter works as a sales person. 

Iuza and Medea plan to diversify the family’s farming activities. In particular, they plan to construct a greenhouse where two products will be grown – tomatoes in summer and greens in the winter period. This will significantly increase the income of the family. According the Iuza’s calculations this business will be profitable and increase the monthly income of the family, now 1000 Laris, by at least 50%.

loans.use: to purchase materials for greenhouse construction.

loans.name: Rochele

texts.en:
Rochele, 33, is married and has four children. Two are in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Rochele has a sari-sari (variety) store business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for five years. 

Rochele requested a PHP 18,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell in her store.

In the future, Rochele would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell in her store

loans.name: Popoteke Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Zimbabwe! This is 48-year-old Maves (holding the yellow folder) from Masvingo. She is married with four children aged 16, 19, 23 and 26.  All four children attend school. She also cares for two dependents. 

Maves runs a retail business selling clothing and footwear. The business has been in operation for 10 years. She says the main challenge faced are debtors failing to pay up on time. 

Maves has requested a loan of $300 to increase her stock. She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow her to improve her quality of life. In the future Maves plans to have grown her business to a point that it can stand alone.

loans.use: to increase stock in her clothing and footwear business.

loans.name: Federico

texts.en: Federico is 51 years of age and is married with seven children. He is a farmer working in the Philippines. Federico's wife is a housekeeper and vegetable vendor. He is asking for a loan to buy inputs needed for their farm such as fertilizers (manure), corn seeds and pesticides. He will also use the loan to pay for preparing the land. In the future, Federico hopes that his business will earn higher income from the harvest to provide for his family's necessities. He also dreams of his children finishing their education and having good futures.

loans.use: to acquire fertilizers, seeds and pesticides.

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina is married and a mother of three school-age children. She is 40 years old and lives in Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. Regina is a farmer. She plants and harvests bananas to earn a living. She sells banana in the local open market at retail and she also sells in bulk to local traders. She has been doing this business for five years. She earns PHP 4,000 a month from this work. She requested a loan of PHP 5,000 at GDMPC to purchase banana tissue culture seedlings.

Regina has been a member of GDMPC for one year. In the future, Regina hopes to have a banana fruit exportation business and gain more profit.

loans.use: To purchase banana tissue culture seedlings.

loans.name: Eliana Yanina

texts.es:
En Los Bajos de Montecristi, ciudad conocida por su gran diversidad de productos típicos, como por ejemplo los sombreros de paja toquillas conocidos dentro y fuera del país se reúnen cada 15  días las socias del Banco Comunal 4 De Noviembre.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Eliana, tiene 29 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene dos hijos de 12 y 8 años los mismos que estudian en colegio y  escuela. El marido es comerciante.
 
Ella trabaja como promotora en el INFA  (Instituto Ecuatoriano de Niño y la Familia) ya hace un tiempo atrás. Ella realiza el crédito para el negocio de su marido, él se dedica a la venta de frutas y legumbres para lo cual tiene un puesto en el Mercado Tarqui en Manta, nos cuenta que él trabaja todos los días desde las 5h00 hasta las 16h00 y que lleva diez años con su negocio, los productos los compra en el mercado a mayoristas o si no a agricultores de la zona por donde vive.

Este crédito es para comprar legumbres, naranjas, papayas, limones, entre otras cosas. Lleva un año  en el Banco Comunal es la fiscal de pagos del mismo y le gusta porque los intereses son más bajos que en otras instituciones de crédito.
 
Su sueño es tener su casa bien terminada y mas grande.
texts.en:
The members of the November 4th Communal Bank meet every 15 days in Los Bajos de Montecristi, a city known for its great diversity of traditional products, such as the Panama hats that are famous within and outside of the country.

It is in this place that one can meet Sra. Eliana. She is 29 years old, in a common-law relationship, and has two children (ages 12 and 8) who are in school. Her husband is a merchant.

Eliana has worked as a promoter for INFA (Ecuadorian Institute for Children and Families) for some time. She is taking out a loan for her husband’s business. He sells fruits and legumes from a stand at the Tarqui Market in Manta. Eliana says that he works every day from 5am to 4pm and has been in business for 10 years. He purchases his products either at the wholesale market or directly from the local farmers.

This loan will be used to buy legumes, oranges, papayas, lemons, and other items. Eliana has been with the Communal Bank for one year and is in charge of collecting payments. She enjoys being a member because the interest rates are much lower than other credit institutions. Her dream is to have a finished house that is larger.

loans.use: to purchase legumes, oranges, papayas, lemons, and other items for her husband's business.

loans.name: Erlita

texts.en:
Erlita is a hard-working entrepreneur who has a food vending business in the Philippines. She is borrowing PHP 23,000 through NWTF to buy additional ingredients for her food vending business.

Erlita has been in this business for 20 years. She earns more income from farming coconuts.

Erlita has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: To buy additional ingredients for her food production business.

loans.name: Walid

texts.en: Walid is a 45-year-old Lebanese married man living with his wife and three school-aged children. He has been working in car electric repairs for more than 11 years. His shop is located in his town and he is known in the neighboring villages too. He sells car spare parts as well. His wife, who works as a teacher in a local school, helps him with the household expenses. Today, he is asking to borrow $2,000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase new electric tools and supplies instead of the used ones. He will also buy more car spare parts. He’s sure that with the new equipment, he will be able to serve more customers, which will return higher profits. In his situation, it’s obvious that he has a real need for extra cash.

loans.use: to purchase electric tools, supplies and more car spare parts

loans.name: Yamile Maria

texts.es: Yamile tiene 35 años y vive al sur de la ciudad con su cónyuge y sus 3 hijos en las edades de 5 a 14 años, allí tiene un negocio de venta de mercancías y alquiler de bici taxis, vehículo utilizado para el transporte en los alrededores del barrio. Ella inició su negocio  de venta de mercancías como ropa y cosméticos, mediante guías especializadas de productos hace más de 5 años, y posteriormente accedió a financiamiento con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo y compró su primer bici taxi para ofrecer este servicio en la comunidad, con el fin de tener un nuevo ingreso como lo hace en la actualidad; con el resultado de su negocio hoy tiene 4 bici taxis  y planea comprar 2 más, pero su capital de trabajo es insuficiente para hacerlo. Esta es la razón por la cual acude a su credikiva, tercer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo con el cual haría esta inversión. Con los créditos recibidos de la Fundación ha invertido efectivamente, estar más holgada y aumentar sus ingresos, además de estar un poco solvente para realizar los gastos del hogar. Su sueño ahora se dirige a tener una casa propia y por eso se esmera trabajando para alcanzarlo; en su negocio maneja una rentabilidad sobre las ventas del 33% y una rotación de cuentas por cobrar de 24 días, de donde parte para impulsar su crecimiento.
texts.en: Yamile is 35 and lives in the south of the city with her husband and their three children who are between the ages of 5 and 14. There she has a business selling merchandise and renting pedicabs, which are used for transportation to the surrounding area. She started her business five years ago selling merchandise such as clothing and cosmetics, using specialized product guides. She has previously recieved a loan from the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo with which she purchased her first pedicab to offer this service in the community. Her goal was to have a new income, which she now does. As a result, her business now has 4 pedicabs. She plans to buy 2 more, but her working capital is not sufficient to do so. This is why she has turned to this Kiva loan. It will be her third loan with the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, and with it she will make this investment. With the loans that she has received from the Fundacion, she has invested effectively, lived more comfortably, and increased her income. She has also been able to cover her household costs. Her aspirations are now turning to having her own home, and with this goal in mind she is working very hard to achieve it. Her business handles a 33% return on sales and a turnover of receivables of 24 days, which boosts its growth.

loans.use: to buy 2 pedicabs.

loans.name: Thoa

texts.en:
Thoa was born in 1957. She is single. She lives in Xom Huong village, Co Loa commune. Her one leg was disabled. So her life is very hard.

She has a general store at home. Her main job is as a cobbler. Besides this, she also knits sweaters, wool hats and wool scarves to sell. She has had this job for many years. She has a monthly income of about 2,500,000 VND. 

She has participated in SEDA since 2004 and always repaid loans punctually. This is the eighth time she is borrowing money from SEDA. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 9,810,000 VND to buy goods to sell and wool for knitting.

loans.use: to buy goods to sell and wool for knitting.

loans.name: Marina

texts.es:
Marina tiene 62 años y es socia del Banco Comunal "Nuestra Señora D. la Paz“ del distrito Tarapoto en el departamento D. San Martín. Es viuda y tiene 6 hijos (3 son mujeres), todos ya son independiente. 

Lleva 10 años trabajando con Manuela Ramos.  Inició su negicio D. venta D. pollos pero lamentablemente lo tuvo que dejar por haber estado enferma. Ahora se dedica a la venta D. productos cosméticos, esta actividad la realiza por las tardes y además ha tenido la idea D. construir algunas habitaciones en su casa para darlos en alquiler. Un joven le ayuda con el negocio. 
Su nuevo préstamo D. S/. 3,000.00 lo invertirá en la construcción D. nuevas habitaciones.

Marina desea seguir trabajando para incrementar su ganancias y construir más habitaciones para alquilar.
Agradece a Manuela Ramos por la facilidad que dan para pagar y los bajos intereses.
texts.en:
Marina is 62 years old and a member of the Communal Bank “Nuestra Señora D. La Paz” (Our Lady of the Peace) which is in the District of Tarapoto, Department of San Martín. She is a widow and has six children (including three daughters). All of them are independent.

Marina has worked with Manuela Ramos for 10 years. She started her business by selling chickens but unfortunately she had to quit because of illness. Now she sells cosmetics since it is an activity that she can work at in the afternoons. In addition, she came up with the idea to build a few rooms in her house that she could make available for rent. A young man helps her with the business.

Her new loan of 3000 PEN will be invested in the construction of new rooms. Marina wants to continue working so that she can increase her earnings and build more rooms for rent. She is grateful to Manuela Ramos for the payment terms and the low interest rates.

loans.use: to build four rental rooms in her house.

loans.name: Rogylyn

texts.en:
Rogylyn is 32 years old, married to a farmer and blessed with three children. She is a very industrious mother. She is sending her two children to school through her hard work. She has been operating her hog-fattening business for nine years and earns an average net income of 10,000 PHP each selling season.

She just finished her high school and never entered tertiary education due to poverty. She wants to avoid this happening to her children, so she is being patient in her work as she stated the fruit of hard work is success. She is asking for a loan amount of 7,000 PHP to buy feed and two hogs to raise in order to earn more income for the betterment of their lives. 

She wants to improve her business in order to provide their educational needs. She is hoping that her children will become respected people someday and then help her to provide financial stability.

loans.use: to buy feed and two hogs to raise

loans.name: Roberto

texts.en:
Roberto is 33 years-old and lives in the Philippines. He is married with four children. 

Roberto is providing motorcycle or habal-habal services. He has had this business for five years. He requested a loan of PHP 11,000 in order to buy tools and pay for the gasoline for the service.

Roberto has been a member of Kiva partner HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Roberto hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy tools and pay for gasoline.

loans.name: Elvio Roberto

texts.es:
El  Señor Elvio está casado, tiene 4  hijos,  todos ellos en edad escolar. El  se dedica a la venta de Zapatos Usados,  en su domicilio.
El comenta que en su negocio le va muy bien por lo que tiene muchos clientes y eso le genera muy buenos ingresos. Dice que todo lo que hace es por darle un mejor futuro a sus hijos, ya que el tuvo que pasar por muchas privaciones y no quiere que sus hijos pasen por lo mismo.
Con la ayuda de su esposa  están  saliendo adelante con mucho sacrificio y dedicación. Hoy día el es un microempresario exitoso con  mucha  clientela, debido a su buen trato. Ha demostrado ser una persona responsable y honesta en sus compromisos por lo que debemos brindarle todo el apoyo necesario.
El solicita el crédito para la compra de zapatos de segunda mano, para la posterior venta, ya que de esa forma podrá cumplir con la demanda de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Sr. Elvio is married and has four children who are all of school age. He sells used shoes from his home.

Elvio says that his business is doing very well because he has many customers and can generate a very good income. Everything he does is intended to provide a better future for his children. Since he had to endure many hardships, he does not want his children to have the same experience.

With the help of his wife, Elvio is able to move forward with great sacrifice and dedication. Today he is a successful micro-entrepreneur who has many customers because of the good service he provides. Elvio has demonstrated that he is a responsible and honest person in all of his commitments, so he is worthy of everyone’s support. The loan he is requesting will be used to buy secondhand shoes for eventual resale. This will allow him to meet the demands of his customers.

loans.use: to buy secondhand shoes for eventual resale.

loans.name: Hesbon

texts.en:
Hesbon is 34 years old, married, and blessed with a four-year-old child.  He runs a grocery, mainly selling fruits to earn a living.  He has been in the business for five years and has employed one person.  He also has a taxi business for more income.
 
Hesbon has managed to grow his business through Faulu Kenya.  His desire is to open other outlets of his business in the future.  He needs 80,000 Kenya shillings to buy fruits.

loans.use: To buy fruits.

loans.name: Nanah

texts.en: Here is a picture of Nanah, a small-scale businesswoman from the city of Makeni, in Northern Sierra Leone. Nanah was born in Makeni, about forty-six years ago. She is married to a businessman and the couple has four children. Nanah has been a businesswoman for the past fifteen years now. She sells “Bamaco” cloths and “gara” cloths (fabric dyed with gara leaves/ indigo dye). She also sells provisions – sardines, milk, sugar, butter, etc. With her loan, she is going to expand her business by buying Bamako and gara cloths, as well as provisions in large quantity to add to her present stock.

loans.use: to buy Bamako and gara cloths, and provisions in large quantity to add to her present stock

loans.name: Sobeida Dubernoides

texts.es:
Sobeida de 36 años, empozo con su negocio de costurera por medio de la cuñada, ahora tiene su propio taller de costura.

Trabaja con empleados desde las 8 de la mañana hasta las 5 de la tarde. Gracias a Dios no ha tenido ninguna dificultad en su negocio. No está casada pero tiene 2 hijos de 11 y 3 años. Tienes muchas aspiraciones con su negocio por eso quiere comprar telas e hilos para mejorar sus confecciones. 
 
Su meta es comprar más maquinarias para así incrementar su taller y así poder implementar más empleados.
texts.en:
Sobeida is 36 years old and started her sewing business with her sister in law.  Now she has her own workshop.  She works with her employees from 8:00 am to 5:00 pm.  Thanks to God she has not had any problems with her business.  She is not married, but has two children, ages 11 and 3.  She has many aspirations for her business and wants to buy fabrics and thread to improve her manufacturing.

Her goal is to buy more sewing machines in order to grow her workshop and be able to hire more employees.

loans.use: to buy fabric and thread.

loans.name: Adau

texts.en:
Adau is a 29-year-old married woman with four children between the ages of 3 and 15. She has been running a shop in Bor, South Sudan, for two years.

Adau is requesting a loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase cooking oil and biscuits to sell. She will use her extra income from this loan to pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: to purchase cooking oil and biscuits to sell.

loans.name: Solomon Mutua

texts.en:
Solomon is a married man. He has three children with ages ranging from 5 years to 19 years. He describes himself as an ambitious man. 

He operates a motorcycle and provides motorcycle transportation services. He has been involved in this business for one year. His business is located in a conducive (to business) environment. He describes his biggest business challenge to be the high cost of fuel. 

Solomon will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy spare parts. His business goal is to venture into taxi transport services within five years.

loans.use: to buy motorbike spare parts.

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es: Margarita es socia del Banco Comunal Hormigas, tiene 59 años, es dueña de una Pollería, también tiene una Farmacia y Hostal que funcionan en su casa, es madre de 1 hijo, es socia de Finca Perú desde hace 15 años, confía en Finca, las capacitaciones le han ayudado a progresar, todo lo que aprendió lo practicó y ahora puede vivir tranquila, al venir a Finca siente como si estuviera en casa, agradece mucho por todo el apoyo que le dieron, durante todos estos años, ahora este préstamo lo invertirá en la compra de pavos.
texts.en: Margarita is a member of the Hormigas ["Ants"] Communal Bank. She is 59 and owns a poultry store. She also has a pharmacy and runs a boarding house from her home. She has one child and has been a member of Finca Peru for 15 years. She trusts Finca. Her loans from Finca have helped her to progress. She uses everything she has learned and is now able to live comfortably. When she arrives at Finca she feels like she has come home. She is very grateful for the help they have given her all these years. She will invest this loan in the purchase of turkeys.

loans.use: to buy turkeys.

loans.name: Ernest

texts.en:
Ernest is a married man. He has three children with ages ranging from 9 years to 15 years. He describes himself to be determined. 

Ernest operates a food stall where he sells fish. He has been involved in this business for fifteen years. His business is located at a residential area. He describes his biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds. He will use the KES 40,000 loan to buy more fish. 

Ernest’s business goal is to be a wholesaler within five years.

loans.use: to purchase more fish.

loans.name: Sanarei Cig Group

texts.en: Sanjana is a 35 year old entrepreneur from Bishnupur. Married and mother of 2 kids, she is the group leader of Sanarei CIG group. She and her husband run a grocery store in their locality. This has been their only source of income for many years now. With this limited income, they have not been able to save much for future needs and emergencies. Other members of the group are also involved in similar income earnings activities. Together, they are applying for a loan of Rs. 75000. The loan amount will be used to purchase bulk stock of in demand products like flour, potatoes, grains, oil etc. The loan will act as a working capital, thereby allowing them to keep up with the demand.

loans.use: To purchase bulk stock of products like flour, potatoes, grains, oil etc for the grocery store

loans.name: Juan

texts.en:
A year ago Juan and his mother opened this small restaurant. They mainly sell food for people on the go and they also specialize in lunch time meals. Juan has been working in this line of work since he was 14 and is now the head of the restaurant although his mother does help him quite a bit. He is 18 years old and studies commerce at a local university during the night time. He is seeking the loan in order to purchase ingredients and dining utensils for the restaurant.

Mifex offers its clients microinsurance and access to business training and educational programs. For more information about microfinance, Ecuador, and our services, please visit www.mifex.org.

loans.use: Ingredients and utensils for their restaurant

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James O. sells different types of books, both new and second-hand. He started his business with a capital of $150 which he had saved while working. He has been in this business for the last five years. He is married and has two children. He has two brothers who depend on him.

Given the funds, he intends to diversify his business by stocking different books and materials to meet his clients' demands. He intends to expand and open a bookshop in the near future.

loans.use: Buy more stock of goods

loans.name: Kak

texts.en: Kak P. is 32 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Phnom Penh, Cambodia.  P. operates a grocery store in her village and generates about $25 per day in revenue.  Her husband, is a driver at a microfinance institution and makes about $7.00 per day.  The couple has two children, one of whom is a student and the other is too young to attend school.  They hope to use this loan to buy more grocery items so P. can expand her business.  Additionally, they hope that they can use this loan to repair their house in order to protect it from leaking during the rainy season.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items in order to expand grocery business and to repair house to protect from leaking

loans.name: Hou

texts.en: Mrs. Hou B. is 24 years old and lives with her husband in Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She is a diligent woman, who has two different sources of income. First, she makes her living by operating a grocery store. Second, she runs a tailoring business. From these two business activities, she typically makes around $8 each day, while her husband assists in generating more income by working as a teacher. Hou B. needs a sewing machine and thread bought in bulk for her tailoring business; that is why she is asking for the loan to help her.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine and thread in bulk for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Juana Patricia

texts.es:
Juana belongs to the Community Bank (Banco Comunal) "El Alto Mayo." She sells clothing exclusively for women and girls because she's says that they are her taget clientele. Her store is located on Jr. Faustino Maldonado Nº 581 in the Rioja district in San Martín. She currently rents the store and is thinking about moving to a location near her home but wants to have it properly equipped first. Juana, 36, is from Piura and has 2 children who are 3 and 8 years old. She believes that it is the charisma and patience she shows her clients that help sustain her business and make it grow. She considers herself to be very independent as far as managing the store. Her knowledge of accounting also helps her manage the finanaces. The loan in the amount of S/.1000.00 ($ 316.00) will be put towards buying intimate apparel for women and girls (2 dozen of the brand Peter Pan), outfits for girls (1 dozen), jeans and workout pants for women (2 dozen each), and blouses and sports polos (2 dozen). She always pays attention to her clients' tastes and needs, and tries to look for the most up-to-date fashion trends in clothing for young people.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Rives, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Juana pertenece al Banco Comunal "El Alto Mayo", se dedica a la venta exclusiva de ropa para damas y niñas, ya que dice que son ellas sus clientes selectas. Su local se encuentra ubicada en el Jr. Faustino Maldonado Nº 581 del distrito de Rioja, en el Departamento de San Martín, es un local alquilado, esta pensando pasarse a un local cerca de su casa, solo espera acondicionarlo. Natural de Piura, tiene 36 años de edad y 02 niños, el mayor tiene 08 años y el último 03 años. Ella cree que el carisma y la paciencia que tiene para sus clientes es lo que la caracteriza, la mantiene y hace crecer en su negocio. Se considera independiente para el manejo del mismo, además de tener conocimientos en contabilidad lo cual le permite manejar muy bien sus finanzas. El préstamo de S/.1000.00 ($ 316.00) lo invertirá en la compra de ropas interiores de damas y niñas (02 docenas de la marca exclusiva de Peter Pan), conjuntos para niñas (01 docena), jeans y pantalones deportivos para damas 02 docenas de cada uno, además de blusas y politos deportivos (02 docenas). Siempre esta pendiente de los gustos y requerimientos de sus clientes, trata de buscar prendas y modelos actuales y juveniles.

loans.use: To buy women's clothing (intimate apparel).

loans.name: Tomasa

texts.en:
Tomasa S. V. is part of the village bank “Señor de Huanca,” which is Spanish for “Father of Huanca,” or the patron saint of Huanca, a region in the highlands of Peru.

Tomasa’s days are split between two different businesses. Every morning, between 6:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m., she can be found in the market selling bunches of alfalfa to customers with livestock to feed. Each bunch costs about 0.50 Nuevo Soles, which is equivalent to about US$ 0.16. Tomasa began her alfalfa business ten years ago when her husband passed away and she was left to support a family of two children ages ten and eighteen. Today her business has grown significantly and she has many regular customers who come to her stand every single morning.

Every evening at 6:00 p.m., Tomasa changes gears to focus on her business selling “emoliente.” For four hours she is at her stand selling this hot herbal drink that combines water, wheat extract, poppy seed extract, fresh lemon, and several other herbs to create a delicious warm tea. It is traditionally consumed in the very early mornings or late at night and is well known for its many medicinal qualities. Tomasa charges about 0.50 Nuevo Soles per glass. She just recently began serving "emoliente" to her community. One year ago, her best friend suggested it as a good additional source of income, and Tomasa already has many regular and very interested customers who come to her every evening for a delicious warm drink.

Tomasa loves being a part of her village bank. She says it has helped her immensely with the growth of both of her businesses. She is now asking for a loan of US$ 500 dollars, with which she will buy more materials for her businesses such as larger quantities of alfalfa and a variety of herbs for her "emoliente".

loans.use: buy materials for her businesses such as larger quantities of alfalfa and a variety of herbs for her hot herbal drink

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Mrs. Esther O. is 50 years old; she is married with 10 children, and lives in Benin City.  She operates a mini-supermarket and she is asking for a loan of $875 to buy more food, wine and fruit juice for sale.  She is a LAPO member.  She learned this business from her mother and started her own business in 2006.

loans.use: To buy more food, wine and fruit juice for sale

loans.name: Fredy

texts.es:
Fredy is 20 years old, originally from the City of Juliaca. He comes from a poor and hardworking family. For the past three years he’s been working in a company that sells and delivers residential gas tanks. He starts work at 6:00 am and finishes at 8:00 pm everyday of the week.

He would like to go back to school and learn a technical skill. Since his schedule is really hectic during the day, he would like to study at night. This is the reason why he comes to you seeking a loan, so he can start going to school and look for a better future. He will pay this loan in full in a period of 6 months.

Translated from Spanish to English by Mayra Villegas, Kiva Volunteer

Fredy es un hacendoso joven de 20 años de edad, desde hace tres años viene trabajando en una empresa privada de venta de gas, exactamente en el área de distribución de gas a domicilio. Él como el resto de sus compañeros de trabajo inician su labor diaria a las 6:00 de la mañana y la culminan a las 8:00 de la noche, todos los días a la semana.El deseo de este joven muchacho, proveniente de un humilde hogar de la ciudad de Juliaca, con grandes deseos de superación, es estudiar por las noches después de concluir su labor diaria, una carrera técnica, con el fin de alcanzar su superación personal. Es por esa razón que recurre a tu buen corazón y hace la solicitud de un préstamo de dinero que se compromete a reembolsar en un lapso de seis meses.Este empeñoso joven requiere de tu pronta ayuda para salir adelante.

loans.use: Registration and first month tuition for the college where Fredy would like to go.

loans.name: Oscar Danilo

texts.es:
For Oscar Danilo G., his own home represents a business, as two years ago he converted his home into a hostel or mini-hotel for those who need the service. The idea for the business came to him when he thought about the many visitors that come to the beautiful city of León who need a place to stay while visiting.

Mr. Oscar Danilo needs to invest in the renovation of his mini-hotel, as the bathrooms, beds and floors have deteriorated over time and it is not in good taste to allow hotel guests to find themselves in these conditions. For this reason, Oscar has very wisely turned to Ceprodel to receive support in the form of credits (currently a total of 6 credits) to invest in the remodeling of his home and business.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva volunteer.

Para Oscar Danilo G., su propio hogar representa su negocio, debido a que desde hace 2 años convirtió su casa de habitación en un hospedaje o mini hotel para los que necesitan este servicio. Surge la idea del negocio por contemplar que son muchos los visitantes a la bella ciudad de León y por tal razón buscan la manera de cómo hospedarse en dicha localidad.

La necesidad que atraviesa el señor Oscar Danilo es que es de urgencia invertir en la remodelación del local tanto como baños, camas y pisos debido a que a través del tiempo se ha venido deteriorando y no es de buen gusto para los clientes encontrarse con tales condiciones. Por esta razón es que muy sabiamente el señor Oscar acude a Ceprodel para recibir apoyo por medio de Créditos (Actualmente un total de 6 créditos) para invertirlos en la remodelación de su hogar y negocio.

loans.use: Repair/remodel bedrooms

loans.name: Dora

texts.en: Dora is a single mother with a ten year old child. She also takes care of another child, who is eight years old. Dora sells clothing. She started her business in 2006. Everyday, she works from 7:00 am to 2:00 pm and can earn a monthly profit of about $140.00 from her sales. She would like a loan to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business

loans.name: Rita's Group

texts.en:
Ana, Rita, and Panila have belonged to the Communal Bank Yana Nawi, which means Black eyes located in Quechua for 3, 2, and 1 years.

Ana is 35 and married with 4 children. She is a loom artisan and makes wallets, hats, and belts. She learned this from her grandparents, and she sells her products in local markets.

Rita is 53 and divorced with 6 children, 3 of which live with her. She sells clothing in demand and her sales have been coming along well. She also sells fruit on foot.

Panila is 23 years old and has one 3 year old daughter. She makes jewelry, which is a craft she learned from her brother. Her sales have been coming along well in the Jesus Nazareno market. Also she sells ceviche (a typical seafood dish from her area).

The three women need a loan of 400 soles each. This money will be invested in the purchase of fabric, thread, ink, cloth, aprons, stones, metal wire, and bracelets.

They hope to improve their homes, build up their businesses, own their own place, and offer a good education to their kids.

Translated from Spanish by James Lombardo, Kiva Volunteer

Ana, Rita y Panila pertenecen al Banco Comunal “Yana Ñawi” que significa “Ojos Negros” en quechua hace 3, 2, 1 años respectivamente.

Ana es casada, tiene 35 años y 4 hijos, Ana hace artesanía en telar como tapices, carteras, gorras, cinturones, actividad que aprendió D. sus abuelos, sus productos lo venD. en los mercados locales.

Por otro lado, Rita es separada, tiene 53 años y 6 hijos D. los cuales 3 viven con ella, Rita venD. ropa D. acuerdo a la demanda, sus ventas lo realiza caminando. Además Rita venD. frutas D. manera ambulatoria.

Mientras que Panila es conviviente, tiene 23 años y 1 hija D. 3 años, Panila hace joyas D. fantasía, actividad que aprendió D. su hermano, sus ventas lo realiza en el mercado Jesús Nazareno. Además Panila venD. cebiche en el mismo mercado.

Ana, Rita y Panila necesitan préstamos D. 400 soles cada una, dinero que será invertido en la compra D. lana, hilo, tinte, fustanes, mandiles, polos, piedras, alambres y argollas.

Los sueños D. Ana, Rita y Panila son mejorar su casa, ampliar sus negocios, tener una tienda D. joyería, un local propio y brindar una buena educación a sus hijos.

loans.use: The three women need a loan of 400 soles each.  This money will be invested in the purchase of fabric, thread, ink, cloth, aprons, stones, metal wire, and bracelets

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Nguyễn Thị Yến, 55 years old, lives with her husband and two children in Lương Bằng, Kim Động. She tends a general sweet stand at the open market in the area. The business fits the weekly repayment plan. Her husband support her business. The average income is 7USD a day. Her grown up children are always help her when she is in need. She’s been with the TYM Fund for 6 years. This time she would like to apply for a loan of 950USD to stock more good for her stand.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Nguyễn Thị Yến, 55 tuổi, sống cùng chồng và 2 con tại thị trấn Lương Bằng, Kim Động. Chị có một quầy bán hoa quả và bánh kẹo ở chợ. Công việc này rất thuận tiện cho việc trả tiền tuần và cũng phù hợp với độ tuổi của chị. Bên cạnh đó chị cũng nhận được sự hỗ trợ tích cực của chồng trong việc kinh doanh. Tiền lãi hàng ngày từ việc bán hàng khoảng 7USD. Con trai, con gái của chị đều đã trưởng thành và luôn hỗ trợ mỗi khi chị gặp khó khăn. Tham gia Quỹ TYM đến nay được 6 năm, chị hoàn toàn hài lòng với những kết quả có được. Vòng vốn tới chị tiếp tục xin vay 950USD để mua thêm hàng bán.

loans.use: Buy fruits, confectionery

loans.name: Emerenciana

texts.es:
Emerenciana is 57 years old and a native of Carabamba. She lives in the district of El Bosque - Provincia D. Trujillo, Departamento D. La Libertad. She has completed her primary studies, has six children, two of whom are still at home pursuing higher education studies.

She sells full meals from home, approximately 45 to 50 daily. She has worked in this line of business since she was young, even while she was still living in her birthplace of Carabamba.

She has been working with Manuela Ramos for about 5 years. With the first loan in the amount of 300 Peruvian soles, she invested in improving her working space and bought some chairs and tables. Emerenciana is a member of the Communal Bank "Amor y Trabajo II" due to the referrals she recieved from other Carabamba members who commented on the Bank's help for women and how these women have been successful through Manuela Ramos. With a loan in the amount of 1000 Peruvian soles, which she will repay in 4 months, she will buy ingredients for preparing food. Her dream is to have a larger working space and a well-equipped kitchen in order to increase earnings and improve her standard of living.

Translated from Spanish by Kara Gibson, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Emerenciana tiene 57 años D. edad, natural D. Carabamba, vive en el Distrito D. El Bosque - Provincia D. Trujillo, Departamento D. La Libertad; curso estudios primarios completos, tiene 06 hijos, D. los cuales dos D. ellos aun dependen del hogar, éstos están cursando estudios superiores. Se dedica a la venta D. menús en su casa, venD. aproximadamente 45 a 50 menús diarios, ella trabaja en este negocio desD. su juventud, cuando aun vivía en Carabamba su tierra natal Con Manuela Ramos viene trabajando 05 años aproximadamente. Los S/. 300.oo otorgado como primer préstamo, los invirtió en mejorar su local para su negocio, compró algunas sillas y mesas. La señora Emerenciana ingresa al Banco Comunal “Amor y Trabajo II ” al ya tener referencias por otras socias D. Carabamba las cuales le comentaron D. su ayuda a mujeres y como salían adelante con Manuela Ramos. Con el préstamo D. S/. 1000.00, el cual será cancelado en 4 meses, lo invertirá en la compra D. insumos para la cocina y elaboración D. menús. Ella aspira tener un local amplio, un restaurante bien implementado y así poder mejorar los ingresos y su condición D. vida.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients to make food

loans.name: Bakhtiyar

texts.en:
Bakhtiyar M. is a 33-year-old man who sells milk in the small village of Saatli. He has more than 20 years of experience in this field. He is married and has two sons.

He sells milk to the milk factory where he also works as a security guard. Working as a security guard pays him the same amount of income as selling milk. His twelve hour work day is becoming a bit tiring. Bakhtiyar would like to focus on expanding his livestock business and purchase two cows with his loan. The estimated cost for one cow is $600.

loans.use: To purchase two cows for milk production and sales to the local factory

loans.name: Thol

texts.en: Mrs. Thol H. is 21 years old and the mother of a child who is too young to work or study.  Mrs. Thol H. is a grocer in Tlok Roloeurng Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. Her husband, Mr. Thorn Thaing, sells firewood. Since his business is going well, Mrs. Thol H., asks for a loan to buy a cart in order to sell firewood door-to-door.

loans.use: To buy a cart to sell firewood door-to-door.

loans.name: Franca

texts.en: Franca U. sells baby items, like baby cream, flasks, dresses, etc. She is 32 years old, and she is married with 6 children. She lives in Uromi Town, Edo State, Nigeria. She has been in this business since 1998. She is a LAPO client. She needs the loan amount of $700 to buy more baby things for sale.

loans.use: To buy more baby things for sale

loans.name: Shahodat

texts.en:
C. Shahodat is 34 years old. She is married and has three children to whom she wishes to give the best. 

Shahodat’s husband is a mechanic, but his income is not enough to cover the family's expenses. That’s why Shahodat has been running her store for 10 years. She sells different kinds of food, accessories for girls, and women socks. 

Shahodat is very dynamic and cares for her family. She tries to give her family as much money as possible to cover the school expenses of her children, because she is dreams that all of them will be well educated. 

Today Shahodat wants to expand her business and to increase her working capital for purchasing new goods to sell. For this purpose, she requests 3700 Somoni ($1100 USD) for 6 months. She has borrowed from IMON several times before and has demonstrated that she is a reliable client. Shahodat promises to manage this loan without any violations.

loans.use: To expand her business and buy new goods to sell.

loans.name: Confiance Group

texts.fr:
Confiance est un regroupement de cinq (5) femmes du village de Kimparana de la préfecture de San (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mail). Vivant dans des familles traditionnelles élargies avec des coépouses et d’autres parents, elles ont en moyenne 40 ans. Toutes mariées, elles sont mères d’au moins 3 enfants chacune.
En plus de l’activité principale à savoir le commerce de condiments alimentaires, elles mènent d’autres activités qui vont de la fabrication et de la vente de boissons locales alcoolisées (tchapalo) et la vente du bois de chauffe.
Liées par des relations d’alliances et de parenté, les membres du groupe Confiance ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis deux ans. Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe), tous les précédents ont été remboursés sans difficulté.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter, une grande quantité de condiments alimentaires ( Oignons, tomates, Laye, Poivres etc….) afin de constituer un stock pour prévenir d’éventuelle rupture en cette période des récoltes champêtres. Les achats sont effectués à Ségou et à Bamako (capitale de la république de Mali) auprès des grossistes et sur commande. Les ventes sont effectuées à domicile, au marché de Kimparana et dans les foires des villages voisins à une clientèle généralement féminine.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen et mensuel de 50 000FCFA. qui servira essentiellement à augmenter la taille de leur activité.
texts.en:
"Confiance" is a group of five women averaging 40 years of age from the village of Kimparana in San Prefecture (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional extended families with co-wives and other parents, are all married, and are mothers with at least three children each.

In addition to their principal business, namely commerce in condiments, they do work making and selling local alcoholic beverages (tchapalo) and selling firewood.

Linked by married and by blood, the members of the Confiance Group decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program two years ago. They are on their fifth solidarity loan (group loan). Each of the preceding ones has been repaid without difficulty. The current loan will be used to buy a large quantity of condiments (onions, tomatoes, "laye", black pepper, etc....) in order to build up an inventory to prevent possible shortages during this harvest season. The purchases will be made in Ségou and in Bamako (Capital of Mali) from wholesale merchants and by special order. Sales are made out of the home, at the Kimparana marketplace, and at the fairs of neighboring villages, to customers who are generally women.

They each envision realizing an average monthly profit of 50,000 francs CFA, which will essentially serve to expand their business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy condiments to create an inventory

loans.name: Trinidad Esperanza

texts.es:
La señora Trinidad pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Divinas, ubicado en el Jr. Apurimac Nº 130, distrito de Callería, provincia de Coronel Portillo, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 61 años de edad, es madre de 10 hijos, 9 mayores de edad y uno que aún depende de ella, es casada y su esposo se dedica al manejo de una motokar. Con el primer préstamo que recibió de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 decide invertir en la venta de comida. Tiene 5 años trabajando con el banco comunal.

En la actualidad se dedica a la venta de ropa a domicilio. En las mañanas se dedica a su hogar y por las tardes reparte su mercadería a sus clientes.

Con este préstamo de S/. 2,000, el cual será pagado en 6 meses, comprará 2 docenas de faldas, 4 docenas de blusas, 2 docenas de pantalones, medias, etc.

Trinidad se siente contenta por todo lo que ha logrado en la vida y agradece a Manuela Ramos por la ayuda brindada.
texts.en:
Trininad participates in the Communal Bank Las Divinas, in Calleria, Coronel Portillo Province, in Ucayali. Trinidad is 61 years old, is married and has 10 children; one of them still lives at home. Her husband works driving a moto-car. The first loan that she received from Manuela Ramos field partner (300 soles) was invested in the sale of prepared food. She has been working with the communal bank for five years. Currently she sells clothing going house to house. In the morning she takes care of her household chores and in the afternoon she visits her customers. She is requesting a loan of 2,000 soles, to be paid back in 6 months. She will use it to buy two dozen skirts, four dozen blouses, two dozen pants, socks, etc. Trinidad is happy with her accomplishments and is thankful to Manuela Ramos field partner for the help she has received.

Translated from Spanish by Maria B., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing skirts, pants, blouses, socks to restock

loans.name: El Tiluchi Group

texts.es: EL GRUPO "EL TILUCHI" ESTA REPRESENTADO POR EL SEÑOR NELSON QUE AL IGUAL QUE SUS COMPAÑEROS RESID. EN EL MISMO BARRIO.  LOS SOCIOS (AS) SE ENCUENTRAN CURSANDO SU SEGUNDO CICLO POR LO QUE YA TIENEN EXPERIENCIA EN GRUPOS SOLIDARIOS Y CANCELARON EL CRÉDITO SIN MAYOR DIFICULTAD DEMOSTRANDO HONRADEZ Y RESPONSABILIDAD EN SUS PAGOS. EN GENERAL LOS SOCIOS SE DEDICAN A ACTIVIDADES COMO LA VENTA D. COMIDAS. ZAPATOS, COSMÉTICOS A LA ELABORACIÓN D. PAN Y REPOSTERÍA AL SERVICIO DOMESTICO Y AL TRANSPORTE PUBLICO. COMO EN TODO RUBRO COMERCIAL SIEMPRE EXISTE LA COMPETENCIA PERO EL OBJETIVO DEL GRUPO ES COMÚN, EL D. PROGRESAR EN SUS NEGOCIOS PARA MEJORAR LA CALIDAD D. VIDA D. SUS FAMILIAS. EL DESTINO DEL FINANCIAMIENTO ES PARA LA COMPRA D. INSUMOS Y PRODUCTOS ASÍ COMO PARA LA COMPRA D. HERRAMIENTAS D. TRABAJO Y LA MEJORA D. SUS NEGOCIOS. EN GENERAL LOS SOCIOS (AS) TIENEN EXPERIENCIA EN GRUPOS SOLIDARIOS PERO ES LA PRIMERA VES QUE TRABAJAN BAJO ESTA MODALIDAD CON LA FUNDACIÓN AGROCAPITAL.
texts.en:
The group, The Tiluchi, is represented by Mr. Nelson and the other group members, who all live in the same neighborhood. The group members are in their second cycle, so they already have experience in these types of groups and have paid back other loans without difficulty, thus demonstrating honor and responsibility with their payments. In general, the members do things such as sell food, shoes, and makeup, bake bread and pastries, proviD. domestic service, and proviD. public transportation. As always in commerce, there is competition, but the group has a common goal: to advance in their businesses to improve the quality of life of their families. This loan will be used to purchase items and products needed to improve services. In general, the members have experience in these sorts of groups, but this is the first time that they have used this method with Kiva partner Fundacion Agrocapital.

Translated from Spanish by Olivia Engkvist, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating expenses

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en:
Mahmoud is a 26-year-old man who lives in Saida, in southern Lebanon. Mahmoud has owned a telephone shop for a year. He has requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase new phones and also accessories for telephones. This is the first time that Mahmoud has requested a loan.

Mahmoud is special in his work because he has a good reputation and knows how to treat his clients. His clients are his friends, neighbors, and others. When he first started his business, he had difficulty finding the right place to open his shop. Mahmoud has learned how to maintain phones. In the future, he plans to expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase new phones and also accessories for telephones

loans.name: Bertha Julia

texts.es: Doña Bertha habita en la Concepción de Maria ubicado de donde fue Polanco una cuadra al norte en la ciudad de Managua, tiene  30 años de edad, con tres hijos de 6,8 y 14 años de edad, los cuales cursan la primaria en la escuela del barrio. Su negocio es la venta de productos ferreteros y venta de madera que inicio desde hace siete años, con fondos propios y prestamos que Afodenic otorgo lo cual se ha beneficiado ya que ha podido hacer su inventario mas grande. Con esta solicitud es la quinta la cual va invertir en madera para realizar su trabajo en las ventas, a futuro es poder mejorar el nivel de vida para poder apoyar a sus hijos con los estudios, a si como captar mas clientes para obtener mejores ingresos.
texts.en:
Berta lives in Concepción de Maria north of the city of Managua. She is 30 years old, and has three children ages 6, 8, and 14, whom attend the neighborhood elementary school. Her business is the sale of hardware and wood that she began 7 years ago with her own funds and with loans that Afodenic granted which have benefited her greatly given that she has been able to increase her inventory. This loan request is her 5th, which she will invest in wood to accomplish her sales goals. Her future hopes are to improve her standard of living to be able to support her children in their studies, as well as to be able to attract more clients to obtain a better income.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase wood to sell in her business.

loans.name: Harriet's Group

texts.en:
Harriet M. is the leader of the Tukwatirewamu group in Jinja. She is a hard-working lady with a bar as her business that has been operational for 7 years. Harriet sells beers, sodas, wines and spirits in addition to the local brew. She is grateful that in addition to having all brands that a customer might need, plus good customer handling, she has been able to retain her regular customers.

She needs a loan to be able to stock more beers and the profits out of it will cater for her children’s school fees and food in addition to what she gets from her garden.

loans.use: More beers to be stocked in her bar.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy chicks, goats, and pigs for his farm

loans.name: Munawar Majid Masih Group

texts.en:
Munawar baji is a 40-year-old married lady and a citizen of a city named Lahore, Pakistan for the last 26 years. Lahore city is famous for its historical places and Punjabi foods. Munawar baji is the mother of three kids: two sons and one daughter. Her elder son runs a tailoring center. The others are enrolled in school and are getting an education. Munawar baji’s husband runs a fruit-selling business. He sells seasonal fruits to the fruit sellers and also goes to the different areas and announces his products in a loud voice. Munawar baji operates a sewing clothes business. She sews clothes for her neighbors and charges them different rates. If the customer orders simple stitching, she charges $2 and if the customer asks for designer clothes, she charges $3. She saves her income in a committee and plans to renovate her house with the committee amount. She has successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more seasonal fruits to expand her husband’s fruit-selling business. 

She is the group leader of three other women from her locality. Janat baji wants a loan to buy thread to sell. Safia baji wants a loan to buy a juicer machine for her juice corner. Jamila baji wants a loan to buy material (colored thread, clothes, sketches) to make dresses for her boutique. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruits to sell

loans.name: Consolacion

texts.en:
Consolacion and her husband have been ice-cream vendors in their village for four years. They live in Cabisera 5, Centro, San Antonio Ilagan, Isabela. They were blessed with three children: Rochelle, a 19-year-old high school undergraduate due to financial difficulties; Rose-Anne, a 17-year-old high school graduate; and Rhea, who is 10 and in grade school. Consolacion and her children have a good relationship and she is thankful for God for having them.

With the business they have, they were able to generate income that supported the basic needs of their family. However, it was not enough to support the education of their children for she still wishes to send her two eldest children to school to pursue their studies. For them to do that, she and her husband must really work hard and look for opportunities to improve their business. Because of this, she is requesting a loan of PHP 10,000.00 that will serve as additional business capital for making ice cream and hopefully, increase their income. Consolacion also shares that success does not only require capital but also requires hard work, diligence and persevering to the best of our ability in our day-to-day work.

loans.use: Business capital

loans.name: María Antonia

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Chinandega, la señora María P. se dedica a su labor de atención de su pulpería el cual posee desde hace 10 años siendo este negocio el que le permite sustentar a su familia.

Ella hoy en día ha acudido a Ceprodel para obtener un crédito para la compra de los productos ya que los necesita con urgencia y para ello espera muy confiadamente en que será beneficiada y así saldrá adelante en su negocio.
texts.en:
In the city of Chinandega, Mrs. María P. has run a shop for the past 10 years. Her shop has supported her family during this time. Mrs. P. came to Ceprodel for a loan to purchase products that she urgently needs, for which she hopes to receive help and move ahead with her business.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Lucas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her business.

loans.name: Limonario Group

texts.es:
Foto De izquierda a derecha: Norman Alberto J., Sara maría H. R. y Narcisa O. A..

Este es el grupo solidario Limonario, conformado por los señores Norman Alberto J., quien se dedica a la venta de comida y refrescos ya preparados, vende de forma ambulante en la zona de Nindirí, tiene muchos clientes y es conocido por la actividad que realiza, es casado y su esposa elabora parte de los productos que vende, son tacos, enchiladas, pollos rostizados , refrescos naturales etc.

Doña Sara María H. es la coordinadora del grupo,los integrantes la eligieron  para este ciclo, ella vende ropa usada en el mercado oriental de Managua, vende ropa mixta, ropa de primera calidad y de segunda calidad. Tiene tres hijos en edad adolescentes, ellos estudian en la escuela del lugar donde viven y le ayudan a vender en la comunidad y entregan encargos de algunos clientes. Su esposo le ayuda con los gastos del hogar, pero él trabaja independiente.
El crédito lo necesita para comprar dos pacas de ropa de primera ya que tiene encargos y para ofrecerá para las festividades del día de la madre.
Doña Narcisa O. A.  es la ultima integrante de este grupo, ella hace y vende  tortillas comida en su casa por las tardes y por las mañanas vende pan, café y leche en el pueblo. Tiene siete hijos, algunos en edad escolar, otros jóvenes que trabajan en la zona franca y adolescentes que le ayudan a vender en la casa y van a la escuela más cercana, su esposo le ayuda con el gasto, está trabajando en Costa Rica y le envía remesas para que se ayude con los gastos del hogar. Ella sueña crecer en su negocio para salir adelante y poder tener comodidades que le permitan trabajar mejor en su cocina, con el crédito compró inventario como leche, café, azúcar, carnes, verduras y dos mesas para atender a los clientes.

Este grupo es originario de la ciudad de Nindirí, responsables, y semi-analfabetas, pero con muchos deseos de superación. Estos señores abonan todos los Lunes, es el mejor día para abonar, después del fin de semana que las ventas son mejores. 


Trabajan con Adim porque una de las clientas le animó que se integrará en un grupo solidario, así ella conformó su grupo con dos amigas cercanas y obtuvo el préstamo. Están contentos porque sienten que la institución confía en ellas y expresan que se proponen a quedar bien en los pagos.
texts.en:
Photo, left to right: Norman Alberto J., Sara María H. R. and Narcisa O. A.. This is the Limonario Solidarity Group, composed of: Señor Norman Alberto J., who is engaged in the sale of ready-to-eat food and drinks. He sells these on foot in the Nindirí neighborhood. He has lots of customers and is known for his work. He is married and his wife prepares some of the products that he sells, such as tacos, enchiladas, roast chicken, natural beverages, etc. Doña Sara María H. was elected by the Group as their Coordinator for this cycle. She sells used clothing in the Oriental Market in Managua. She sells various types of clothing, the best quality as well as lesser quality. She has three adolescent children. They are attending school near where they live and they help her by selling in the community and taking orders from some of her customers. Her husband helps her with the household expenses but he works independently. She needs the loan to buy two lots of first quality clothing for which she has orders and which she will offer during the Mother's Day festivities. Doña Narcisa O. A. is the last member of this group. She makes and sells tortillas in her house in the afternoon, and in the morning she sells bread, coffee and milk in the town. She has seven children: some are of school age, other youngsters are working in the tax-free area, and her adolescent children help her to sell out of her house and go to school nearby. Her husband helps her with the expenses. He is working in Costa Rica and sends her remittances in order to help her with the household expenses. She dreams of growing her business so she can get ahead and be able to have the amenities that would allow her to work better in her kitchen. She will use the loan to buy ingredients such as milk, coffee, sugar, meats, vegetables and two tables to accommodate her customers. This group originated in the city of Nindirí. They are responsible and semi-literate but they have a great desire to better themselves. These people pay every Monday, which is the best day to make payments, after the weekend when their sales are the best. They are working with ADIM because one of the other clients encouraged them to form a solidarity group. And so Sara organized her group with two close friends and obtained a loan. They are satisfied because they feel that the institution trusts in them and they expressed that they intend to be good with their payments.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Kvaka, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various products for sale.

loans.name: Lucresia

texts.es:
La señora Lucrecia, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Semillas del Futuro” ubicado en el distrito de Puno, Provincia de  Puno, Departamento de Puno. Tiene 41 años de edad, es casada y 2 hijos, posee estudios de secundaria completa y vive en el Barrio Ricardo Palma.

Trabaja con el movimiento Manuela R. hace 2 años con un préstamo inicial de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles para su negocio de compra y venta de artesanías de cerámica. 

Actualmente solicita un préstamo de S/. 800.00 Nuevos soles, para poder invertir en su actual negocio, comprando artesanías de cerámica y además lana de diferentes colores para elaborar artesanías en tejidos a palito.

Su mayor sueño es darles una educación a sus hijos.

A ella le gustan las charlas de apoyo a las mujeres que realizan en su banco comunal.
texts.en:
Lucrecia belongs to the Semillas del Futuro Community Bank, which is located in the Puno district, Puno province, Puno departments. She is 41, married, and she has two children. She has a high school education. She lives in the Ricardo Palma neighborhood. She has worked with the Movimiento Manuela R. for two years. She started with a loan of 300 PEN, which she used for her business of buying and selling ceramic handicrafts. She is currently asking for a loan for 800 PEN to buy ceramic handicrafts and different color wool to make the handicrafts that she knits. Her biggest dream is to give her children an education. She likes the chats that support the women, which are held by her Community Bank.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy ceramics and different colors of wool

loans.name: Lê Thị

texts.en:
L. Lê Thị (10250660772) is a 33-year-old female living in the town of Nghi Lộc. She is married and has two school-aged children.

L. owns and operates a business running a general store, primarily selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in this business for over seven years and earns approximately 3,000,000 VND a month.

In 2004, L. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000,000 VND from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding her business.

L. is now requesting a new loan of 10,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. The loan will be her 5th from TYM Fund. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice M. has a small bar where she sells cooked rice and stew at Abura. Alice has received junior high school education. She is married and has four dependents and is responsible for paying school fees and utility bills. Her husband is a driver.

Alice has been selling cooked rice and stew since 2001. The loan will be used to buy bags of rice to run the business on a larger scale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to expand the business.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice to run the business on a larger scale

loans.name: Maria Antonia

texts.es: María Antonia R. M. tiene la actividad económica de una pulpería. Hace más de 3 años que se dedica a este negocio. Ella tiene 39 años de edad. María tiene 3 hijos, y todos estudian por el mayor sacrificio que realiza Doña María. Su negocio se dio porque ella decide vender bolsas de hielo y refrescos por lo que tuvo bastante influencia de clientes, por lo que le genero ciertas ganancias y decide invertir un poco más en este negocio. El financiamiento que solicita es para capital de trabajo para la compra de productos como golosinas, jugos, refrescos, pan, detergentes, jabón entre otras cosas. Su mayor sueño es ofrecer un buen servicio a sus clientes y proporcionarles mejoras a su vivienda.
texts.en:
Maria Antonia R. M. has run a small grocery store for the past 3 years. She is 39 years old and has 3 children, all of whom, thanks to Maria's great efforts, are full-time students. She began by selling bags of ice and soft drinks which generated a good client base that led to decent profits. Now she would like to invest a bit more in her store. The financing she is seeking is to purchase inventory items such as snacks, juices, soft drinks, bread, detergent, soap, etc. Her greatest dream is to offer her clients good customer service and to be able to make improvements to her home.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase inventory.

loans.name: Jovie

texts.en:
Jovie brought success to her family for being productive in her 'sari-sari' store (community-based store) in their village of Cutog Grande Reina Mercedes, Isabela. She has been operating her store for seven years and she is making a weekly net income of PHP 1,000 which she uses as rolling capital and for the school expenses of her children.

Jovie wants to improve her business and so she would like to borrow additional capital from Kiva lenders in the amount of PHP 5,000. She hopes that the loan will give her a bigger chance to have a progressive business.

Jovie is 26 years old and married to Bonifacio, a farmer. They are blessed with four children: Angelica - 11 years old, already in grade school; Erica - 8 years old; Johny Vic - 4 years old, and their youngest is Mariel - 2 years old. Jovie hopes to give all her children a better education that will somehow lift them from poverty.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Corazones De Oro Group

texts.es:
Silvia Justa O. presidenta del grupo “Corazones de Oro”, que pertenece al Centro Focal “Los Andes”, dirige su reunión  y juntas elaborán su reglamente interno. Este grupo se funda hace aproximadadamente 5 años, todas sus integrantes tienen diversas actividades económicas como tejido de prendas de vestir, compra y venta de ropa, papa, pan, revistas y comida. Un ejemplo claro es Carmen Q. de 25 años, vende revistas en la feria 16 de Julio y desea adquirir más mercadería, otra integrante es Neri C. de 33 años, vende pan en la ex tranca de Rio Seco, todos los días y quiere incrementar su mercadería. Tereza C. de 59 años vende ropa en diferentes provincias como Achacachi y Palcoco.
Todas ellas necesitan el préstamo para comprar mercadería y materia prima
texts.en:
Silvia Justa O., president of the “Corazones de Oro” Group (a branch of the Los Andes hub), leads the group members, and together they work within their internal regulations. This group was founded approximately 5 years ago. The group members have different businesses, such as knitting apparel, buying and selling clothing, potatoes, bread, magazines, and food sales. A clear example is Carmen Q., age 25, who sells magazines at the 16 de Julio market. She would like to obtain more merchandise. Another member is Neri C., age 33, who sells bread in Ex Tranca Rio Seco every day, and wants to increase her inventory. Tereza C., age 59, sells clothing throughout several provinces, like Achacachi and Palcoco.

They all need the loan to purchase merchandise and raw materials.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise and raw materials

loans.name: Anyimisye

texts.en: Mambo (greetings) from Tanzania! This is 42-year-old Anyimisye S. from Mbeya. She is married with six children between the ages of 11 and 22. Anyimisye has been running a business since 2000, purchasing and selling fish. She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, six days per week and currently earns about 80 USD from her business. Anyimisye is requesting a loan in order to purchase fish in bulk for her business. In the future, she plans to improve the quality of her business. She thanks you for your support! About SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy fish in bulk

loans.name: Nemicia

texts.es:
Nemicia tiene 60 años, vive en su casa propia con su esposo y sus 3 hijos. Toda su vida ha estado ligada a las tareas agrícolas, pero actualmente enfoca sus esfuerzos a la actividad ganadera. Todas las mañanas sale a pastear a sus animales a zonas alejadas D. su casa, demorando hasta 2 horas D. camino hasta llegar a campos con pastos frescos y regresa aproximadamente a las 5 D. la tarD.. Pero cuando es la época D. siembra o D. cosecha ella y toda su familia participan en estos trabajos, pues son muy duros para una sola persona. Nemicia siente mucha gratitud por la agricultura porque durante muchos años, con ella, pudo sostener las necesidades D. sus hijos. 

Esta es la primera vez que tiene un crédito con MFP y se siente muy contenta D. formar parte D. un banco comunal, por lo que se compromete a ser responsable en todos sus pagos. El dinero que ahora solicita será destinado a la compra D. medicina para sus animales y también sacos D. abono.
texts.en:
Nemicia is 60 years old and lives in her own house with her husband and their three children. She has been involved in agricultural work her whole life, but now she focuses her energy on ranching. Every morning, she takes her animals to graze in areas far from her house, spending up to 2 hours on the road before arriving at fields with fresh pastures, and then she returns around 5 in the evening. When it is planting or harvesting season, however, she and her whole family participate in this work, which would be very difficult for only one person. Nemicia is very grateful for her agriculture, because for many years it has allowed her to proviD. her children with the essentials. This is the first time she has received a loan from MFP and she is very happy to be part of a communal bank, so she is committed to being responsible with all her payments. The money she is soliciting now will be used for the purchase of medicine for her animals as well as sacks of fertilizer.

Translated from Spanish by Julia Kastner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizer and medicine for her animals

loans.name: Cajina Group

texts.es:
Blanca Azucena A. Casjina, Sofía Amplié C. y María Lidia M. Dávila conforman al grupo C.. La señora A. de 52 años vende productos esquimo, ella comenzó porque un día le toco vender en la iglesia como sobraron los llevo a su casa y observo que había una gran clientela actualmente vende diario en su casa y los fines de semana en el templo.

Eskimo un empresa nicaragüense que elabora productos lácteos diversos, tales como helados, sorbetes, leche y sus derivados. Es la mayor compañía heladera fundada en 1942 y que tiene presencia en todo el país.

Sofía Inés Amplié C. comenzó vendiendo helado y comida a empresas aledañas a su casa pero como serraron puso una panadería en las que hace donas y reposterías. María Lidia Dávila vende chocodananos, helados, tajadas con queso, enchiladas y los fines de semana vende en la iglesia.
texts.en:
Blanca Azucena A. Casjina, Sofía Amplié C., and María Lidia M. Dávila comprise the C. Group. A., 52, sells Eskimo (dairy) products. She started because one day it was her turn to sell at church. She took what was left over to her house, and she saw that there were a lot of customers. She currently sells daily from her house and in the church on the week ends. Eskimo is a Nicaraguan company that makes diverse dairy products like ice cream, sorbet, milk, and its derivatives.
