Peintre de profession, Monsieur D. est un artiste reconnu dans le milieu de par la qualité des services qu’il rend. Son atelier étant démoli, il est contraint de rester à la maison faute de moyens. Cependant, il est de plus en plus sollicité et il ressent la nécessité de réaménager son atelier où les gens peuvent le retrouver au moment opportun. Il sollicite un crédit de $1000.

loans.use: To refurbish his shop

loans.name: Amelia

texts.en:
Amelia, 35, took her first loan for her porridge business. She repaid the loan with no problem, but decided that a secondhand clothing business would be more profitable. She took her capital and started selling bags, shoes and clothes at the Fatamantu market in Accra. She’s been there for two years now and would like to expand her business with more stock. With the loan, her profits are expected to raise approximately $30 a week.

Amelia currently lives with her 12-year-old and 7-year-old in a rental house with many other families. She hopes to build a house for just her family when she has enough money.

Amelia is a member of the lending group, Yaweh. The group guarantees a loan through a group repayment pledge. Peer pressure and support provide the incentive to repay; if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the payment amount. The photo shows Amelia (center left) with some members of her lending group.

loans.use: To purchase secondhand clothing

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Improve his shop and buy an industrial kitchen.

loans.name: Karla Vanesa

texts.es:
Karla is a hardworking woman, who runs a grocery store at home, in the city of León. Five years ago, as she was not able to find employment and was going through a difficult financial situation, she decided to invest her meager savings (4000 córdobas, aproximately 215 US dollars) in the purchase of products for sale.

As every working woman, she opens the doors of her business very early to serve her faithful clientele. It is important to point out that she has been a good Ceprodel client for two years, requesting loans that she has used to stock up on merchandise and, in this way, support her family.

Translated from Spanish by Leticia Britos, Kiva Volunteer.

Karla es una dama muy esforzada y trabajadora. Se desempeña en la venta de abarrotes en la ciudad de León, específicamente en su casa de habitación. Desde hace 5 años por la difícil situación económica que atravesaba debido a que no encontraba empleo en ningún lado, decidió invertir sus pocos ahorros (cuatro mil córdobas) en la compra de productos de pulpería para venderlos.

Como toda mujer trabajadora, ella desde muy temprano abre las puertas de su negocio para atender a su fiel clientela. Es necesario destacar que desde hace dos años ha sido una fiel cliente de Ceprodel, solicitando créditos que los utilizado para surtir su tienda y de esta manera poder mantener su núcleo familiar.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise.

loans.name: Yi

texts.en: Yi K. E., 54, is a widow with seven children.  Together with her eldest daughter, she raises ducks, earning on average $2.50 a day. One of her other daughters works as a hair dresser and another works as tailor in Phnom Penh City.  Each month they send $50 to Yi.  The rest of her children are students. Yi would like to borrow $500 to buy duck food and to spend on her children's education.

loans.use: To purchase duck food.

loans.name: Maria's Mwembeni Group

texts.en:
Maria is 32 years old and is a single woman. Maria is a cloth seller; she started her business in 2005. Every day she works from 6:00 AM to 7:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

In the past, Maria has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Agnes, who has a business dealing in cloth selling.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy food for bear

loans.name: Flor De Liz

texts.es:
Flor S. is a woman who, for a long time, has been working to see out her dreams of improving her living conditions that have been challenged over the years and have caused her to keep adapting. Since beginning the work of reconstructing her house, she has looked for loans from Ceprodel to buy construction materials. Again she is looking to Ceprodel for a loan that she will use for continuing the reconstruction of her house through the purchase of construction materials.

She requests this loan out of great need, as she is a single mother with the responsibility of raising her two school-aged children.

Translated from Spanish by Maggie Messerschmidt, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Flor S. es una dama que por mucho tiempo se ha venido esforzando trabajando para ver cumplido su sueños de mejorar las condiciones de su vivienda ya que ha sido azotada fuertemente por los años y le ha urgido invertir en ella. Al haber iniciado la obra de reconstrucción de su vivienda ella ha solicitado créditos en Ceprodel para la compra de sus materiales de construcción. Hoy en día una vez mas muy sabiamente acude a Ceprodel solicitando un préstamo con el cual continuar con la reconstrucción de su vivienda por medio de la compra de los materiales de construcción.

Es de suma necesidad destacar que ella es madre soltera y con la responsabilidad de mantener a sus dos hijos en edad escolar.

loans.use: To buy construction materials

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To increase the inventory of items for sale

loans.name: Florida

texts.en:
Greetings from Rwanda! Florida is 30 years old, a single mother with four children and three adopted orphans from the 1994 Genocide.

She is a businesswoman who sells bananas and fish in the Rubavu market in Gisenyi. She earns about US$ 100 every month. Through the profits she earns from her business, Florida has been able to build her own house. She is requesting a loan worth 504590 Frws (US$ 925) to boost her business because of the increase in customers.

loans.use: Increase her working capital

loans.name: Luz Elizabeth

texts.es:
Luz Elizabeth P., only 25 years old, lives in Lourdes Colon. She has a small son that she supports and raises on her own, since she has been a single mother for the past six years. Despite filling the role of both mother and father, Luz Elizabeth has always looked ahead and expressed her entrepreneurial spirit by opening a small bakery with her mother two years ago. The bakery represents her only means of income, and the vehicle through which she helps her family financially as she lives with her parents and two brothers. With a strong desire to get ahead, Luz is soliciting a loan to invest into her business. The loan will help her buy an industrial oven and prime ingredients to allow her to grow economically and provide a better future for her family and her son.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

Luz Elizabeth P. vive en Lourdes Colon, con tan solo 25 años de edad, Luz tiene ya un hijo pequeño, a quien cría y mantiene como madre soltera desde hace ya seis años. A pesar de ser tanto padre y madre de familia, Luz Elizabeth ha mirado siempre hacia el frente, y denotando emprendedurismo abrió junto a su madre una panadería propia hace ya 2años. La panadería constituye su única fuente de ingresos, y el medio mediante el cual ella ayuda a su familia, pues vive con sus padres y dos hermanos. Con un vivido anhelo de superación, Luz solicita un préstamo para invertir en su negocio, y así comprar un horno industrial y materia prima que le permita crecer económicamente y proveer un mejor futuro para su familia e hijo.

loans.use: Purchase an industrial oven and prime ingredients.

location.town: Lourdes Colón, departamento de La Libertad

loans.name: Fatma's Bites Seller Group

texts.en:
Fatma is married and has three children who are between 12 and 21 years of age. She has been a bites (snacks) seller since 1998. Every day, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90.

Fatma is requesting a loan to improve her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses selling charcoal and soft drinks.

loans.use: To improve her business.

loans.name: Fatma

texts.en:
Fatma has been selling charcoal in Zanzibar since 2006. Charcoal is the primary fuel used to cook food in Tanzania as few families own ovens or stoves. Fatma works from 8 a.m. to 9 p.m. every day and earns a profit of approximately $100 each month. She will be using her first loan from BRAC Tanzania to buy more charcoal so that she can increase her sales.

Fatma is 26 years old, married, and has two children, ages 3 and 5.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to sell in her shop.

loans.name: Guisenia

texts.en: Guisenia is a member of the Amor y Esperanza (“Love and Hope”) Village Bank. She is 30 years old and is a single mother to an eight-year-old son. Guisenia works in the Carmen Alto Market selling grains; she has been in this line of work for the past 10 years. Guisenia is requesting a loan of 600 soles to buy different kinds of flour (e.g. flaxseed flour, wheat flour) and dried beans and corn. Guisenia’s dream is to finish building her home. She’s almost finished; she just needs to install the roof.

loans.use: Buy flour, dried beans and dried corn

loans.name: Johana Elizabeth

texts.es: Johana esta solicitando su 4to refinanciamiento para invertirlo en  mejora de su vivienda como es construir una habiatación, labora como contador y docente en la Universidad URACCAN zona Urbana de  Nueva Guinea desde  hace 8 años, actualmente esta estudiando un post grado en Universidad URACCAN recinto Nueva Guinea, se caracteriza por ser humilde, responsable, honesta y con muncho deseos de superación personal y profesional, profesa la religión evangelica. Tiene un hijo de 8 añitos que estudia su tercer grado de educación primaria, viven en el barrio Linda Vista de Nueva Guinea donde la población cada dia crece mas,  su mayor sueño es tener estabilidad laboral, una vivienda bonita y que su hijo estudie para que sea persona de bien.
texts.en:
Johana is asking for a refinancing of her fourth loan to invest in improving her home by building a room. She has worked as an accountant and teacher in the urban zone of New Guinea at the URACCAN University for 8 years. Currently, she is doing post-graduate work at the Nueva Guinea campus of URACCAN University. She is humble, responsible, honest, and has many dreams of succeeding personally and professionally. She professes evangelical religion. She has an 8 year-old son who is in third grade. They live in the Linda Vista de Nueva Guinea neighborhood where the population grows more each day. Her greatest dream is to have job stability, a beautiful home, and for her child to study to have a better life.

Translated from Spanish by Joanna Silverman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction of a room

loans.name: Zeinab

texts.en:
Zeinab, 52, is a widow that lives with her two children in Saida, a city in southern Lebanon.  Zeinab has owned a clothing shop for 10 years.  Her clients are her friends, neighbors and others.  When Zeinab first started her business, she faced social and economic conditions.   

She requests a loan for $1000 USD from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her shop.  This will be her third loan, and she has always repaid her loans on time.

loans.use: Zeinab will use the loan to purchase merchandise for her shop.

loans.name: Laureta

texts.en:
Laureata T. is 52 years old and has been a vegetable vendor for 19 years. Her husband is a farmer named Jimmy. They have three children: Loujane, 19, currently studying in college; Louie, 17, and Allan, 15, both in high school. Their family is strongly bonded and living a healthy lifestyle. 

She hopes to send all her children to school and to finish college. Laureata and her husband are always willing to sacrifice to achieve their children’s desired education. Thus, Laureata wanted a loan amounting to PHP 6,000.00 that will be used as additional capital for her business. Through the loan, Laureata will purchase more vegetables of different varieties and will sell them to their village. She prays that she will be able to get a loan with her simple business proposal so that she will be able to achieve her goals in life through patience and hard work.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables to sell in the village

loans.name: Lidia Auxiliadora

texts.es:
La señora Lidia Auxiliadora G. es propietaria de su propio negocio de cafetín donde vende reposterías, gaseosas y café desde hace 19 años en el mercado Mayoreo de la ciudad de Managua capital del bello país de Nicaragua. 

A diario la señora Auxiliadora percibe ingresos los cuales son utilizados para el mantenimiento del negocio y de igual manera para bendecir a su pequeño hijo ya que ella es madre soltera. Actualmente ha acudido a Ceprodel con el fin de ser beneficiada con un crédito para la compra de los comestibles como reposterías y bebidas para ofrecerlas en el negocio y mejorar sus condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Lidia Auxiliadora G. owns a small cafe, where she has sold snacks, soft drinks, and coffee for the last nineteen years. Her cafe is located in the Mayoreo market in the city of Managua, capital of the beautiful country of Nicaragua. Each day, Mrs. Auxiliadora earns revenue that she uses to maintain her business and to care for her young son, since she is a single mother. She has sought out Ceprodel in hopes of receiving a loan that she will use to purchase food products, such as snacks and beverages, that she can sell in her business and improve the living conditions of her family.

Translated from Spanish by Leah Karlins, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase food and drinks for her cafe

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en:
Faustina O. is 46 years old. She is married and has given birth to five children: three boys and two girls. Her last born is in junior high school. The rest are out of school and working. She lives with her children and husband in a family house in a small farming community called Nkwateng in the Eastern Region of Ghana. The major occupation of the inhabitants, the men in particular, is farming. Most of the women, however, are into trading activities and palm oil production. Faustina’s husband is a mason by profession.

Faustina produces palm oil to make some income to support her husband financially. She procures palm fruits from the local farmers and nearby farms. She distributes to customers who come to buy in bulk and retail. Faustina also sells to food vendors and wants a loan to procure palm fruits in bulk so that she can produce the oil in bulk and distribute to her increasing number of customers. She hopes to improve her living standard and give her children the best support she can.

loans.use: To procure palm fruits to expand her palm oil business

loans.name: Eka

texts.en: Eka L., 36, is married with three children.  She has one year of experience in the pancake business. She sells to the villagers and the school six days per week. She has had one previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 425 Tala. SPBD loans are Eka’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase plastic bags, drippings, oil, salt, and cooking utensils

loans.name: Marlyn

texts.en:
Marlyn is a direct seller of Avon and Natasha products. She is 37 and married with two kids. Their eldest child is in elementary school while the youngest is at preschool. They are residing in the village of San Roque Centro, Enrile Cagayan, an agricultural-based community. Her husband manages their little corn and rice field.

Through her business, she was able to assist her husband in providing for the needs of their family. She makes use of Avon and Natasha brochures for her customers to shop for their orders. Some of her products are clothes, makeup, jewelry, footwear and so on. She wants to have more capital for her business and someday be able to have her own Avon and Natasha outlet in their town. However, she knows that it will take a lot of time, effort and patience and enough capital.

She is hoping for a loan of PHP 10,000.00 for her business to grow. She is earning an income on a commission basis of 25 percent for every PHP 100 sales. She hopes to increase her income for the future of her family. Marlyn believes that with her income, she will able to save money for the future of her children and to improve their house.

loans.use: Business capital

loans.name: Pilar

texts.es: el Sr. Pilar tiene 64 años de edad, el se levanta a las 5 de la mañana para irse a la terminal de buses de la localidad para comprar las semillas en sacos y fardos de maiz y frijoles, esto es para venderlo en diferentes caserios y comunidades cerca de donde el vive, su producto lo vende por libras y asi obtiene una buena ganancia, el maiz se vende muy bien ya que de ahi se hacen las tortillas, este alimento con los frijoles es indispensable en muchas familias de nuestro pais. el necesita el credito para comprar mas mercaderia y asi tener mejores ganancias y poder salir adelante con su familia.
texts.en:
Mr. Pilar is 64 years old. He wakes up at 5 in the morning to go to the bus station in his town to buy sacks of seeds and bundles of corn and beans. He sells all of this in different hamlets and communities near where he lives. He sells his product by the pound and, in this way, he earns a good income. The corn sells very well since tortillas are made from it. This food, along with beans, is indispensible for many families in his country. He needs this loan to buy more merchandise and, thus, to have more earnings and to be able to go forward with his family.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy corn and beans in seeds and bundles

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Felicia A. is fifty years old. She is married and has given birth to three children: two sons and one daughter. She says they are in senior high school and the polytechnic. She lives with the children and her husband in a rented apartment in a very busy commercial town called Goaso, in the Brong Ahafo Region of Ghana. Felicia’s husband is a teacher while she is a trader. She works very hard to help her husband to provide for the family. Felicia trades in groundnut paste. 
She buys bags of fresh groundnut from Kumasi and sells on a tabletop in her community market. Felicia says she also treks to other towns to sell on their market days. She has been in business for over thirty years. She is hopeful to expand her business and increase her profit margin. Felicia desires to sponsor her children in school to high levels.

loans.use: To buy bags of groundnut.

loans.name: Alhaji I

texts.en:
This is Alhaji Issa S.. Alhaji is a local entrepreneur in Magburaka town; he sells medicine at the town’s main market. This will the fifth loan Alhaji is accessing from SMT/Kiva. Previous loans have made a tremendous impact into the live and business of this entrepreneur. Having made his last loan repayment as member of a solidarity group, he is now asking for a loan of SLL1,000,000 as an individual client.

Alhaji was born in Magburaka town, fifty-four years ago. He is married to a businesswoman and they have eight children. Three of their children are in Senior Secondary School, three in Junior Secondary School and two in primary schools. Alhaji Isssa S. has been selling medicine for over twenty-two years now. This loan will go a long way in helping Alhaji, he told me. Being able to buy the drugs in wholesale alone has saved him enough money, when compared to receiving the drugs from wholesalers.

loans.use: To invest in his business.

loans.name: Unidos Al Progreso Group

texts.es:
Irma Olinda Huamán Calderón, tengo 49 años de edad, hace tres años participo como presidenta en EDAPROSPO-PROSPERIDAD en la alcancía comunal “Unidos al Progreso”, los doce integrantes que formamos esta ALCOM nos dedicamos al comercio, la llamamos así porque si estamos unidos, el progreso será para todos.
Siempre tuve la idea de generar mis propios ingresos, para ello empecé a vender chups de frutas en mi casa, además hacía servicio de costura. Esto me generó pequeñas ganancias que pude comprar golosinas; pero sentí que quería seguir creciendo, para ello era necesario contar con un capital el cual no lo tenía. Por tal motivo acudo a EDAPROSPO – PROSPERIDAD a fin de obtener el crédito, lo que ayudó a crecer más mi negocio, quien diría hoy en día es una pequeña tienda que pienso seguir implementando con los siguientes préstamos que recibiré de EDAPROSPO-PROSPERIDAD hasta verlo convertido en una bodega. Hoy me siento una mujer superada con el apoyo de EDAPROSPO – PROSPERIDAD, no sólo ayudó en los gastos, también pude darle una mejor calidad de vida a mi hijo (especial) de 24 años.
texts.en:
Irma Olinda Huamán Calderón, I am 49 years old. For 3 years I have been the president of EDAPROSPO-PROSPERIDAD in the community group “Unidos al Progreso” (united for progress). The 12 members of our group work in retail, we call ourselves “Unidos al Progreso” because we believe that being united will bring us progress. I have always had the initiative to generate my own income. In order to do that, I started selling fruit candy from my home. I also worked as a seamstress and these activities generated a small profit with which I bought more sweets. I felt that this business could move forward but I needed some capital that I did not have. For that reason, I reached out to EDAPROSPO – PROSPERIDAD in order to obtain a loan to help me improve my business. Who would have thought that I would now have a small shop, which I intend to continue improving with additional loans from EDAPROSPO – PROSPERIDAD until it is converted into a grocery store. Today I feel very fulfilled with the support of EDAPROSPO – PROSPERIDAD, it has not only helped me with expenses, but has also helped me provide a better quality of life for my 24 year old disabled son.

Translated from Spanish by Mariana Hungria, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy Supplies for Shop

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret E. is married and has four dependents. She received schooling through primary education. Margaret has established herself in the business of selling  plastic bowls at Amissano in Elmina. Her husband is a cleaner. Margaret uses her income to pay bills. Margaret is requesting a  loan to purchase more plastic bowls. Having more inventory will increase her income, which will help Margaret save to buy a piece of land and build a house.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: For growing corn

loans.name: Isabel

texts.en:
Isabel E. is 48-year-old laundry shop owner in Tagbilaran Bohol  started her business in 2004. She has four children and dreamed to be successful always in her business to be able to support the needs in their family.

She would like to ask for a loan of Php 12,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy washing machines for her business expansion. She likes the services of CEVI because it has a very low interest rate which is 2% a month.

loans.use: buy washing machines for her business expansion

loans.name: Nancy

texts.es:
Nancy es una socia dedicada  a su trabajo, optimista y con gran deseo de salir adelante, tiene 35 años de edad, es madre de 3 hijos menores de edad, ella se dedica a la venta de comida como Juanes(arroz envuelto en hojas), tacacho (plátano machacado), arroz chaufa, chuleta de chancho a la parrilla. Cuenta con el apoyo siempre de su esposo, cuyo trabajo es maestro de construcción. Nancy es una socia activa, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Dulce Vida II”, desde hace dos años.  Su primer préstamo fue de 300 soles, monto que invirtió en la compra de insumos para la venta de comida. 
Con este préstamo de S/. 1000 soles, piensa invertirlo en la implementación de su negocio de menús, comprará insumos e ingredientes para la preparación de sus alimentos.  La meta de Nancy  es construir un local donde funcione su restaurante  y seguir apoyando a su esposo en la educación de sus hijos.

loans.use: Invertirá en la implementación de su negocio ( venta de menús).

loans.name: Successful Women Group

texts.en:
Successful Women is a group of five borrowers led by Sarah M., 32 years old, a single mother with two children aged 1 and 10 years old, with the oldest child's educational level at 5th grade. She also cares for a sibling.

Sara is a schoolteacher by profession but decided to get into business in order to support herself and her children financially.
She lives in Virginia, a community that is mixed with both poor and middle-class Liberians. It is in the northern part of Monrovia, the capital.

Sarah's business is hairdressing. She has a very small salon in Virginia where she does hairdressing for the residents of that community. She has been running this business for more than three years and is doing well. Because Sarah gives the residents of Virginia good service, and also has a good relationship with her customers, they always want to have their hair fixed in her salon.

Sara dreams of establishing a bigger salon in the future which will enable her to build a house for herself and the children. She needs this loan in order to purchase more hair products and salon materials.

loans.use: To purchase more hair products and salon materials

loans.name: Joel

texts.es:
Joel tiene 30 años, vive con su pareja y madre de sus 3 hijos, en su casa propia. Se dedica a la siembra de papas, arvejas y gladiolos en sus propias chacras, donde generalmente trabaja solo; pero para las temporadas de cosecha necesita el apoyo de su esposa. Para Joel, sembrar papa le resulta más rentable, ya que la vende como semilla, los pequeños y los más grandes los envía directamente al mercado de mayoristas de la ciudad capital (Lima), donde le pagan un mejor precio. Estas ganancias las invierte en la compra de fertilizantes e inmediatamente prepara la tierra para la siembra de arvejas y así no desperdiciar los nutrientes de esa chacra. Gracias a que Joel aprovecha al máximo sus terrenos ha podido conseguir el dinero necesario para solventar las necesidades de su familia durante todos estos años.

Este es su cuarto crédito con MFP, donde está muy agradecido por el apoyo constante de su asesor de créditos, pero lo que más le gusta es que ya tiene ahorros. El dinero que solicita lo va invertir en la compra de fertilizantes químicos para sus próximas siembras de papa.

loans.use: Compra de fertilizantes

loans.name: Gilda Celeste

texts.pt:
Gilda M. nasceu na cidade de Maputo, tem 39 anos de idade, casada e mãe de 1 filho de 20 anos de idade. Vive na casa própria com a família e 2 netos de 4 e 2 anos de idade. Fez 4ª classe e parou com os estudos quando perdeu seus pais cedo e não teve quem a pudesse sustentar.
	
Nunca saiu da Província, mudou se para o Bairro T3 em 1992 para se juntar ao seu marido. Ė negociante e Modista a mais de 10 anos, tem 2 auxiliares que ajudam nas vendas e trabalha cerca de 10 horas por dia. O produto que mais vende são lençóis que adquire a 1.800.00MT localmente e na Republica da África do Sul. Rende cerca de 3.500.00MT por mês e aplica nas despesas caseiras. O seu marido trabalha como técnico de saúde na organização, Médicos Del Mundi. Possui uma conta bancaria onde deposita suas poupanças no Banco de credito TCHUMA.
 
Já teve empréstimo numa associação cujo nome já não se lembra, e este é o seu 1º empréstimo na Hluvuku no valor de 15.000.00MT com o qual pretende comprar fardos de roupa uni sexo (camisas, camisetes e lençóis).
Conheceu a Hluvuku através de uma amiga vizinha que também é cliente desta instituição.
Com este empréstimo espera aumentar o seu rendimento para poder responder as necessidades primaria de casa e no futuro solicitar mais empréstimos, com o objectivo de construir um estabelecimento de vendas.
texts.en:
Gilda M. is from Maputo, Mozambique. She is 39 years old, married and the mother of a 20 year old. She lives in her own house with her son and and two grandchildren aged 4 and 2. She has a business selling clothes and other fabrics, activity that she's been performing for the past 10 years. She has two employees and works around 10 hours a day. Her best selling product are bed sheets that she buys in South Africa to resell in Maputo. She makes around 3.500,00MT (U$120) per month and uses the money to support her household. Her husband works at the Medicos Del Mundi organization as a health technician. This is Gilda's first loan and she's asking for 15.000,00MT (U$525) to buy clothes and sheets to resell.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of clothes to resell

loans.name: Ana

texts.es:
la señora Ana R. tiene 58 años de edad, vive en union libre con el señor Felipe Cruz quien labora vendiendo agua y jugos en su carrito en barrios y colonias de San Lorenzo, la señora R.
es muy emprendedora y dinamica siempre ha realizado actividades de comercio con su esposo, asi ha podido salir adelante ella y su familia. Ana vende herbalife en su casa tiene muy buena clientela. esta solicitando el prestamo para comprar medio fardo de ropa usada, calzado, agua, jugos y producto herbalife.
su sueño laboral es ser la mejor supervisora de ventas de herbalife.
texts.en:
Ana R., 58, lives in a common law marriage with Felipe Cruz. He works selling water and juices from his cart in the neighborhoods and areas surrounding San Lorenzo. Mrs. R. is very enterprising and dynamic. She has always worked in commerce with her husband. That way she has been able to get herself and her family ahead. Ana sells Herbalife in her house. She has very good customers. She is asking for the loan to buy half of a bundle of used clothes, footwear, water, juice, and Herbalife products. Her dream for work is to be the best sales supervisor for Herbalife.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy water in bags, juice, shoes, and Herbalife products

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta C. is a 36-year-old married woman with three school-age children, living in the village of San Manuel. To make a living, Julieta operates a family member's business venture in the retail sector; indeed, she operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling chicharron to the local community, using her tricycle for transportation. Julieta has been engaged in her business for several years, and she explains that she earns approximately 8,000 PHP per month from these activities.

Julieta joined ASKI to gain access to financial services so that she would be able to engage in business activities. In turn, she hoped to improve her living situation. Julieta is now requesting a loan in the amount of 11,000 PHP ($250), which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated as a result of this loan to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches, covering the Central and Northeastern areas, and its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen/women, and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional products for resale purposes

loans.name: Um

texts.en: The photo shows Mrs. Um H., age 53, who is a widow and mother living in a small wooden house located along the river. Um H. has three teenage children, two of whom are employed (one sells souvenirs and one is a boat driver) and one of whom is a student. To make a living, Um H. always wakes up in the morning to go to the busy fish market where she is hired by buyers to carry their fish. She typically earns an average of $3 each day to support her family. Um H. requested a loan to repair her older house that breaks frequently.

loans.use: To repair her older house

loans.name: Khaled

texts.en:
Khaled is a single young man, 26 years old. He lives with his parents and his 5 siblings whom he loves dearly He has the responsibility of taking care of them and wants to increase his income in order to give his family a better life. 

Khaled operates a grocery store in his neighborhood. He started his operation one year ago. He sells products like rice, canned foods, drinks, candies, etc. With the loan, Khaled wants to buy more products to increase his stock of goods.

loans.use: To increase his supplies of groceries

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian A. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 43 years old. Lilian is married and has six adult-aged children. To make a living, Lilian owns and operates a retail store, selling a variety of goods like jackfruit (common fruit with multiple uses) and papaya as well as dry goods like noodles, canned goods and more in the local community. Lilian is just starting this business.

In 2009, Lilian joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Lilian is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to develop her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Tomas Alberto

texts.es:
Tomas es socia del Banco Comunal Juanito.
Tomas es casada, tiene 43 años y 2 hijos, Tomas es técnico relojero, tiene un kiosco en el mercado magdalena en donde brinda sus servicios, actividad que realiza todos los días.
Tomas necesita un préstamo de 600 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de repuestos de reloj.
Los sueños de Tomas son mejorar su negocio e implementar otro negocio.
texts.en:
Tomas is a member of the communal bank Juanito. Tomas is 43, married with 2 children. He is a watch repair technician with a kiosk in the Magdalena market where he provides his services, an activity that he does every day. Tomas needs a loan of $225 to invest in the purchase of watch spare parts. Tomas dreams of increasing his business and of starting another business.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of watch spare parts

loans.name: Dorn

texts.en: Mrs. C. weaves bamboo baskets for sale. She sells her finished products to buyers who come directly to her house. She makes many sets of baskets before selling out. She also orders baskets from the other villagers and sells them to make additional income. Her husband (he is pictured) helps her sell and weave baskets. Recently, C. has run out of essential materials from her stock supply and she hopes to acquire other raw materials to continue making baskets. She depends on using her Kiva loan as an advance. The family lives with two kids who are enrolled in school.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials.

loans.name: Guerlita

texts.en: Fifty-nine-year-old Guerlita R. is a married woman who has supported her family with her general store and food-vending business for over twenty years. She lives with her her husband, Rodolfo, and their two adult children at Purok Mainawaon, Barangay Tabot-ao, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. Guerlita has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and food-vending businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 30,000. Guerlita is now borrowing Php 12,000 so that she can expand her general store and food-vending businesses. This will be her 9th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 7,000, which she paid off within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Guerlita aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her businesses

loans.name: Luzminda

texts.en: Luzminda D. is from the village of Owaon. She is 61 years old, is married, and has three adult children. Luzminda owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 1,800 PHP a month. In 2006, Luzminda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase pig feed and other supplies. Luzminda is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase piglets to raise and sell. This loan will be her 8th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise and sell

loans.name: Mrs. Saroem Nhor Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan, which consists of nineteen members, is located in Kandoeng ThU. village in Takeo province. All the members plan to use their loans for different purposes.

Mrs. Saroem N. is the village bank president who has been selected by the other members. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to grow rice to feed her family. Her husband is a dessert seller. Although they work hard at their careers, they still earn little income. They want to start a new business, but they don't have enough money. Thus, Mrs. Saroem N. decided to apply for a loan to buy some piglets, pig food for breeding pigs, and dessert for resale. She is the mother of five children: one attends the local public school, while the others are seamstresses in a garment factory.

loans.use: To buy some piglets and pig food for breeding

loans.name: Esther

texts.es: Esther tiene 20 años, actualmente convive con su pareja y fruto de ello, tienen una hija. Juntos viven en su casa propia, ubicada en la selva cuzqueña. Esther, una joven soñadora y trabajadora, recuerda que antes de tener su tienda, ofrecía sus productos tocando puertas, sin tener que estar esperando algún cliente que la busque, de esa manera sus ventas crecían al igual que sus ingresos. Con el tiempo obtuvo una lista de clientes fijos, eso le dio ventaja para instalar su tienda, ofreciendo a todo el público en general, variados productos a precios competitivos. Usualmente trabaja con su pareja, pero en ocasiones recibe la ayuda  de sus padres y su horario de trabajo empieza desde las 5:00 AM hasta las 9:00PM. En lo sucesivo desea ampliar su tienda con la finalidad de seguir satisfaciendo a sus clientes. Este es su cuarto crédito con MFP, por el cual se compromete a cumplir con su obligaciones de pago, además agradece a su grupo comunal por el apoyo que le brindan. Con el crédito que solicita lo invertirá en la compra de productos, con el propósito de surtir su tienda.
texts.en:
Esther, 20, lives with her partner and their daughter in their own home located in the Cusco jungle. Esther, a hard-working, hopeful young woman, remembers how she used to sell door-to-door before she had her store; she didn’t wait for customers to find her. Her sales grew as well as her income. In time, she secured a base of repeat customers that gave her the edge she needed to open her own store; she stocks an assortment of products that she sells for reasonable prices to the general public. She usually works with her partner and sometimes her parents help her. She is open for business from 5am until 9pm. In the future, she would like to expand her store to continue to satisfy customer demand. This is her 4th loan with MFP and she pledges to repay in a timely fashion. She is also grateful to her communal group for the support they give her. She will use the requested funds to buy stock items for her store.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy stock items for her store.

loans.name: Heng

texts.en:
Mrs. Heng A., 32, was a grocery seller when she was single, but now she is married to Mr. Roeun, 31, who is a construction laborer for a small firm. They are both good parents of two kids who are enrolled in school.

Recently Heng A. sold nearly all her grocery items.  She hopes to supply more items for her store but she does not have enough capital, so Heng A. is applying for a $400 loan in order to buy a variety of items that she sold such as cooking ingredients, sweets, snacks, soft drinks, cane goods, and plastic goods.

loans.use: To buy cooking ingredients, sweets, snacks, and soft drinks.

loans.name: Martires

texts.es:
El  señor Martires es soltero, tiene 38 años de edad, el mismo es dueño de una panadería donde produce infinidades de productos  panificados en forma artesanal,  situado en la ciudad de Pilar, sobre la calle 4ta proyectada c/ Avda. Mcal Lopez., en dicho local se comercializa productos variados en general, como panificados en general, como ser pan común , galletas de todas las variedades, masitas, tortas, etc.
Es un importante 5 años en el Ramo, con gran cantidad de clientes. El Cliente cuenta con casa propia, en la misma casa cuenta con su panadería.
El cliente comercializa sus productos en toda la ciudad y el interior del Departamento.
Solicita el crédito para invertir en la compra de insumos (harina, levaduras, dulces, y otros) para su  panadería y agradece nuevamente a la fundación paraguaya por los buenos servicios que le ha brindado a su emprendimiento.
texts.en:
Martires is single and 38 years old. He is the proprietor of a bakery that produces a variety of artisan bread products. The bakery is located on Mariscal Lopez Avenue in the city of Pilar. Here, Martires sells products such as common bread, all varieties of cookies, cakes, sweets, etc. Martires has been in this business for five years and has many clients. He has his own house, at the same location as the bakery. He sells his products all over the city and in the interior of the department. Martires is seeking a loan to buy ingredients (flour, leavening, sweets and others) for his bakery. He is thankful, once again, to Fundación Paraguaya for the good services it has offered his business.

Translated from Spanish by jeffrey hersk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy ingredients and supplies for bakery

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace has been a van operator for three years and is happily married with one son who attends school. Her husband works with Pan Africa. Grace rents a house with electricity but no piped water. She told us that her greatest monthly expenses are food and rent.

With the Kshs 80,000 loan, Grace wants to purchase new parts for her van and do some painting. She decided to join Yehu to obtain the loan to uplift her business, her potential customers being her passengers. She faces the challenge of high competition since many vans are operating on the road.

In the future, Grace hopes to begin a tourist company.

loans.use: To purchase new parts for her van and do some painting
